reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my steam playtime, I have much longer logged on my boxed copy and still play to this day. It's a game I enjoy so much I bough a steam copy just for backup purposes.

The end of an era, it marks the last great tactical shooter on the market before this series descended into mediocrity. Nothing else since this has come close to equalling its quality of brutal, unforgiving tactics. This is a game that wears its realism on its sleeve and isn't afraid to let you drop dead from one bullet fired from a guy you couldn't even have seen coming. You move slowly and even walking throws your aim way off. Repeated autofire might as well be fired with your eyes closed. Guns feel weighty and impactful, dropping enemies in one or two torso shots.  It's harsh and doesn't feel remotely fair at times, but having smooth, flawless success in this game is more satisfying than any other shooter I've played.

Unlocking all the maps requires playing through the campaign mode, where the iffy team AI and permanent injuries/death to the squad members can make things frustrating, but if you take the time to plan things out they usually go well. The game has no tolerance for the slightest mistake, for even a single corner left unchecked, and requires awareness and caution you rarely need in other games.

The real fun comes with friends. Competitive modes are fine, but nothing's better than the sheer teamwork it takes to clear out a whole map in co-op. And the sheer disaster that can strike if any one of you slips up for a moment. Multiplayer no longer functions out of the box, so you'll have to take alternate methods to get it work, such as Hamachi or Tunngle, but it's well worth the effort. Still one of my favourite coop games of all time.

reviewText:
Rating: 9/10

Rainbow Six III is a squad-based tactical shooter set in the beginning of the 21st Century. You lead a counter-terrorism unit called RAINBOW, assembled from elite soldiers from NATO countries. As can be expected from the Tom Clancy universe, the story and missions essentially boil down to there are 'bad guys' going 'bad stuff' and you have to stop them. There's a lot of nostalgia surrounding the reputation of this game, particularly around it's depiction of realistic squad operations in tight environments. From a realism perspective there are significant issues with the game, but from a gameplay perspective this is one of the finest tactical shooters ever made. Most engagements occur at less than 30 metres, and enemy fire is accurate, responsive and highly lethal, so the margin of error is small. It's essential that you use proper positioning, team tactics, and the appropriate tactical aids to suit the environment.

In reality, special operations are meticulously planned down to the smallest detail. Typically, the environment is reconstructed in a training ground, missions are planned by the second, and the mission is practised for hundreds of hours before the real mission ever takes place. If an event demands an urgent response, with no time for practice, special operations still still require an extremely detailed mission plan. This aspect of special operations is realistically modelled in the game using pre-mission planning tools. You are given a map of the entire grounds and can set a sequence of way points, go-codes, and special actions (e.g. throw flashbang, face direction). You can choose to have the AI play out the entire mission, where you will only be issuing go-codes from the command centre. Alternatively, you can play as a single operative and command the squad in person. You can switch between squad members, queue orders across several squads, and issue a single go-code to activate all orders at once (e.g. breach and clear a room from three different entrances at once).

Friendly AI is fairly limited in the unmodified game to either following the planning sequences or following the player controlled operative. Planning ensures that team members will follow precise instructions, but they'll be unable to do anything else. Without pre-mission planning, friendly AI is limited to following the player and firing at visible enemies; they will not face to cover the player's side and rear flanks. Enemy AI is limited to three behaviours: (1) Patrol; (2) Stand and shoot; and (3) Walk towards the sound of gun fire. Raven Shield 2.0 (ModDB) is a graphics and AI improvement mod which dramatically alters friendly and enemy AI. However, enemy AI will still have difficulty hearing gunshots from afar, and can't work in groups or use tactical positioning.

The equipment available is fairly standard to shooters, including a variety of standard primary (e.g. M16A2 assault rifle) and secondary firearms (e.g. M92 pistol), as well as tactical aids in the form of grenades (e.g. flashbang, concussion, fragmentation, smoke). Given the limited range of engagements there is virtually no bullet drop, and small arms accuracy is depicted realistically. Weapons damage is also depicted realistically, but only for unarmoured opponents.

Armour protection is not modelled realistically. Armour gives users a maximum of 2 hit points, which affects the entire body. Regardless of where targets are shot, they will no longer be able to run. The US National Institute of Justice (NIJ) classifies levels of armour protection for police officers. Level III armour consists of two solid metal plates covering the front and back of the torso. In reality, Level III armour stops virtually an unlimited number of pistol calibre rounds and at least half a dozen 5.56x45mm NATO rounds, with very little backface signature (i.e. deformation of the inside of the armour plate). However, in the game a single 5.56x45mm NATO round, or three 9x19mm Parabellum rounds, will incapacitate the target.

Fragmentation grenades are not modelled realistically. Confusingly, frag grenades have their real world effects split between frag and concussion grenades in the game. Frag grenades only do damage within a blast radius. Concussion grenades will kill everyone in a small room through the concussive wave reflecting off the walls, floor and ceiling, but are completely ineffective outside of small rooms. Conspicuously absent from the equipment are wide angle night vision goggles (NVG), though this may be because the technology was not developed or publicly known when the game was being developed.

I love this game. This game was one of my very first gaming experiences. Before Neopets. Before Pokemon. Before my PS1 and Xbox. Before Warcraft 3 and Diablo and all the other good stuff. I used to play this all the time with my dad, and as such constitutes some of my fondest childhood memories.

Anyway, let's dive right in.

This game has technical issues. The menus are locked to 800x600 (?) resolution, though the game itself supports much higher resolutions. It did 1080p just fine for me. However, due to the different resolutions, your resolution will fluctuate whenever you enter/leave the menus. Kind of annoying, but no big deal. You better get used to the low resolution though, because you'll be spending a lot of time in the planning menu. Which brings me to my next point...

This is not your typical action FPS. It's relatively slow paced and you spend a lot of time planning things out. There are 3 teams you can customize. You can outfit each team member with different armor, weapons, weapon attachments, various types of grenades, and various utility tools. During planning you can dictate where your teams go, how they go there, what they do when the reach there, etc.

reviewText: The last real Rainbow Six game. I'm not saying this due to opinion. The name 'Rainbow Six', in the Tom Clancy universe, refers to the leader of the multi-national counter-terrorism SOF 'Rainbow'. In every Rainbow Six up to this one (original, Rogue Spear, Covert Ops), you take that role; assigning team members to squads, choosing each member's loadout, creating a plan for each team to carry out during the course of each mission. Then you can either spectate or take control of one of the teams. You really can't even compare or argue the Rainbow Six games that came out after this because they are basically a different genre with different fans.\n\nPost-Rainbow Six 3 (Lockdown, Vegas, Vegas 2, etc.) you only take control of a single protaganist throughout the entire game. You can't plan out the mission because the missions are linear and setpiece-focused, much like traditional FPS games. And while the Vegas games were still fun and you were still a member of Rainbow, you did not assume the position of the commander, Rainbow Six, in these games. And unfortunately, no big-name developer has made a game simliar to the old school Rainbow Six games in well over a decade.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Graphics still hold up to this day!
- OUTSTANDING sound, especially with a headset. Each shot is not a toy, but a terrifying panic-enducing alarm which you must keep a level head through to survive.
- Damage makes sense - shot with a 9 mil? Are you wearing armor thick enough to stop it from killing you? Your leg is injured, you are limping and bleeding in pain. That shotgun is too close, there is no surviving that.
- Monumental gameplay mechanics (described in my rant below)
- SO MANY MODS!

Cons:
- No online servers left alive (aside from 4 or 5 hard-to-find custom servers)
- AI is overpowered in some moments and stupid in others



Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six 3 - were to start? I have infinite praise for this game.

This game is undeniably aged, but the gameplay mechanics still remain a pillar of tactical shooters to this day. Whether you go on a mission with a team of expert counter-terorist operatives, or you head into a mission lone-wolf, alertness and strategy is key to success - your life, your team's lives and the lives of helpless hostages all depend on your execution, which cannot be anything less than perfect.

Before each mission you may chose from a range of multi-national Rainbow Operatives to accompany you on a mission. Each operative has his/her specialty - be it alertness, stealth, leadership or skills with various equipment from breaching charges to sniper support to clearing rooms in close-quarters combat. It is up to you to decide each member's loadout (primary, secondary, type of ammunition, accessories, armor type, etc.,) You may chose to go in with a single squad or split up into 3 separate squads. Then comes the fun part - mission planning: drawing up a master plan takes time and dedication to carrying out a successful mission with zero casualties. Doing so you can rely on your fellow squad members to carry out your plans perfectly automatically - while you are sweeping the basement another squad that you assembled will sweep the roof for you, according to plan. But beware, everything relies on perfection.

reviewText:
Truthful in its nature of strategy and action, R63 is quite undeniably the last true tactical game to have come in the series.
Pitting you in a what-would-be a spec op's worst nightmare scenarios too crazy for real-life, you're given simple objectives that usually encompasses rescuing hostages, preventing certain destruction, and all the while killing everyone else in sight (enemies do rarely surrender though). The levels are great and complex, but some may prove to be too much of a challenge, with some of the most unforgivingly tough gun combat you'll face. As hard as it can get, this instead left me craving for more for some reason.
Enjoyment is however, marred by a few technicalities to the likes of the occasional dumb but crazy aimbotting enemy AI and slightly underwhelming gunplay. What's more annoying is the incompetency of your own teammates, who may fare well in the easier levels but get completely obliterated in certain, more assault-oriented levels. Ultimately it doesn't matter how much strategic map planning comes into play, it all boils down to the player's own level of FPS skills for the best success, which puts into question the real importance of the tactical aspect.

Regardless, this game goes far behind SWAT 4 as one of the best tactical shooter I've ever played. And given the state of the Tactical Shooter genre that has since died off in gaming trend, this position will always remain as such, sadly.

reviewText: Rainbow Six 3 is considered the best installment in the Rainbow Six series by many, and for a very good reason. reviewText:
Raven Shield is what many (myself included, if I'm honest) consider to be the best Rainbow Six game, as all the following entries in the series either fail at realism, (Lockdown) or straight-up take the 'arcade' route. (Vegas)

It's often compared to the likes of Counter-Strike, and I'd honestly say that it's better. This is because it adds a lot more to the table in terms of weapons, game modes, maps, decent AI opponents and team mates, as well as allowing you to perform more actions; as an example, you're able to 'fluidly' open doors so you can silently open it a crack to peep through, just swing it open, or even put a breaching charge on it.

In terms of weapons/gadgets you can use, other than having literally a mountain of guns to pick from, (although I always say the FNC and Steyr AUG are the best ;) ) ranging from assault rifles, sniper rifles, sub-machine guns, shotguns, light machine guns and pistols (including automatic pistols), there are a whole load of grenades and other equip-able items you can pick from. For example, there are of course your typical frag and flashbang grenades in the game, but there are also CS teargas (and gasmasks you can take to counter this) and smoke grenades. Not to mention the various other explosives and utilities, such as claymores + remote detonators (no magic hostile presence-detecting ones like in other games), C4 explosives, heartbeat detectors and many more.

Also, the iron-sight haters won't have a problem with R6 3:RS either, as they've still got the good ol' zoom - which shouldn't be an issue for those who dislike the zoom, as there are plenty of choices with scopes of varying types, as well as other attachments for your weapons.

So yeah, essentially if you want to play a realistic and fun shooter with loads of different tactics and choices, get this!

reviewText: This is the benchmark for tactical shooters on the PC, and has yet to be surpassed by any other game. Raven Shield and the other original Rainbow 6/Rogue Spear games are true tactical counter-terrorism simulations, based on real weapons and tactics used in modern day counter terrorist operations. You plan your mission, you don't get to save during a mission, and it's one-shot and you're dead. No regenerating health, and when an operative dies it is final. I love Raven Shield because of the punishing difficulty, and emphasis on being the first to spot your opponent and quickly aim for the head. I think this is a good representation for close quarters combat, as close as you can get to real life.\n\nI love this game, and it's sad to see the Tom Clancy and Rainbow Six licenses being sold down the river. Everything after RVS and Athena Sword has been dumbed down garbage for the masses. Rainbow Six was never meant to appeal to the call of duty or counter strike crowd, it was in a class of its own. I got this game when it came out in 2003 and I just re-installed it, and it's as good as ever. I've beaten the single player 4 times, twice on elite, and it doesn't get any better than the feeling of successfully completing a mission with no fatalities. I have spent countless hours on multiplayer, which is also great too. I can only hope they make more games like this, because there are no modern games that come close to realism and tactical depth like Raven Shield does.

reviewText: Rainbow Six 3, like most of Tom Clancy's titles, is a squad-based tactical shooter with a lot of depth. This game favors tactics over action, and you will spend hours planning out each mission before actually playing it. Before a mission, you can choose who goes on what team (Alpha, Charlie, etc.), choose their loadouts (a lot of weapons to choose from, each with their own advantages and disadvantages), and plan out the mission waypoint by waypoint. Once you are comfortable with how the planning stage works, you can coordinate attacks from multiple angles, give go-codes to execute orders, set the rules of engagement, and so on. The game gives you the option to either play through the mission or watch the AI do what you have told them to do. It's a really nice option, because it's basically two totally different styles of gameplay. You can play it as a strategy game, being the man calling the shots, or play it through the eyes of a Rainbow operative. Pick this one up.

Great game, one of my all time favourites. Its worth buying at sale time for $5. You should get about 40 - 80 hours out of it. Be sure to have a look at gameplay and reviews to see what its like (apparently is quite different to the newer Rainbow Six games) in that it is very tactical, think SWAT 3 and SWAT 4.

Also, in terms of multiplayer I cannot comment as I haven't played multiplayer.

Single player is great. You get about 17 missions in a campaign and 8 skirmish maps to play on for Rainbow Six 3, and a campaign with about 8 missions and 8 skirmish maps for the Athena Sword add on pack included in this Gold Edition. Also, you can download for free the Iron Wrath expanision pack which adds even more missions and maps (there is plenty of info out there about how to get this going for the Steam verison).

The missions are usually about killing or terrorists, saving hostages and diffusing bombs in a tactical way. A fair bit of time is spent planning and replaying the missions and this may be a turn off for those who just want action. A few other modes are available including terrorist hunt, hostage rescue and lone wolf that add to replayability. There are about 60 odd guns in the game with everything from submachine guns to sniper rifles plus things like CS gas and stun grenades.

Downsides:
- A fair bit of time is spent planning as opposed to playing eg a usual mission will take about 10 minutes of planning and 5 minutes of action but expect to be replaying the mission and doing the planning phase plenty of times over.
- Enemy and friendly AI can be really bad at times.
- Old game (2004?) so graphics aren't going to be great.
- I'd say buy it at sale time for a big discount as at $10usd you may feel ripped off.

reviewText: A realistic game, if you can call a shooter that. Exteremely quick (and in the campaing, permanent) death, slow movement and the ability to carry only one rifle, one sidearm and 6 grenades at most are somewhat realistick but don't believe it when people call this game hyper realistic. The game's immersion is broken easily by things like hip-fire reticlespread applying even when using a scope. The relatively braindead ai is a known problem, but it doesnt matter because the enemy isn't supposed to do anything else than react to hearing gunfire and fire at you when they see you. Your teammates on the other hand do just fine, because they do as they are told and don't improvise anything stupid. Except when they decide to fall off from a ladder and die, forcing you to restart the mission. The pseudo-randomized enemy placement and the sometimes unreliable teammate ai make sure that however well you plan your missions, you will need at least one retry before you get the desired no casualty -run. The fact that planning your mission can take up a good 20-30 minutes and executing the plan take a rough 5 min depending on mission. That is, if you get it working on the first try. Fixing your plan between retries can easily take up a cumulative 30min unless you have to redo the plan altogether. All that combined and you can waste an evenening just trying to complete that one hostage recue. The game can be very frustrating on the other hand very satisfying when you finally complete that one mission. Despite everything negative I said about the game, it is in my opinion an enjoyable experience. Just as a word of warning: This is not an fps Dark Souls, in this game you move a lot slower but die a lot faster. You can end up 6 feet below in a literal heartbeat. Have fun.

I was already familiar with the original Xbox version, though my memory of it isn't detailed, and the semi-modern Vegas games. Both Vegas games have their fair share of problems, including bad third-person cover systems, enemies that spawn behind you, nonsensical instant deaths, sound glitches, and (in the case of Vegas 2) a sprint function that makes the multiplayer feel more like a slower CoD than a tactical shooter. Everyone on the internet told me that RS3 is better in every way, the definitive tactical shooter.

They were wrong.

Rainbow Six 3 has enemies that can't hear gunfire from 10 feet away or see their friends die right in front of them, but they are quite capable of seeing through brick walls and hearing footsteps from across the room. On more than one occasion, I died at random, one time by an explosion that didn't have an accompanying grenade or terrorist.

The weapon selection is decent, though I find it hard to find anything to be excited about. You can customize your weapons by choosing between features like an extended mag, a scope, or a silencer. Some weapons have multiple ammo types which don't really matter in a terrorist hunt. Character customization does not exist, but it isn't really needed.

Movement is slow, but that's to be expected. What isn't expected is the painfully slow sidestep. Having manual control over the motion of opening doors, crouching, and leaning is interesting and will probably be useful for hardcore players. The most welcome function is the ability to lean around corners. That's what tactical shooters are: Q and E to lean. Not recommended.

reviewText:
tl;dr This game is a tactical shooter, so it may not be for everyone. It can still be fun to play with people, granted they know what they are doing. The game may have some technical flaws (it being old). If you want to play good old Rainbow Six without wrestling with the Original's engine, pick this one up.

Rainbow Six 3 is a squad based, tactical shooter. This game allows you to take control of the elite counterterrorism unit RAINBOW (yes, that's the name of the unit).

This game is not something you rush into. You need tactics. The game has an entire planning phase where you can modify how each group of operatives moves. You can tell them to wait on your mark, then when you give the go-code, open the door and flash through it.

Multiplayer still works, however you have to have a uPlay account. You could try lan or hamachi, but I didn't test that.

The game has a mutlitude of weapons and armor for you to choose. You can use silenced smgs with flashbangs and go full on stealth, or use 50.cal snipers and M4's with frag grenades to go all out.

This game is also not as easy as your usual FPS. You get a maximum of 1-3 hits before your dead. Everyone follows this rule. Once someone's dead, they can no longer be chosen, so make sure your teammates don't die.

The game also has some mechanics that I've never seen any other FPS have before, or after. These are the fluid lean and door opening. Using the mouse, you can adjust your character to lean at many other angles other than one. Fluid door opening allows you to open doors halfway, a tiny bit, or just enough to let a grenade through.

reviewText:
This game is the benchmark against which I measure all other tactical shooters and trust me when I tell you that practically no other game that has come out after Raven Shield measures up to it. SWAT 4 is very close but RVS comes out on top. In Rainbow Six 3 you take control of an international counter-terrorist unit called Rainbow and your job is to prevent terrorists from doing whatever it is that they are trying to do. To achieve this you use the powerful mission planner to plan your mission to the finest detail, coordinating up to three teams or a maximum of eight operatives. The planner will let you do anything you need to do to get the job done. For example you can set up go-codes to clear a room from multiple directions simultaneously. You can define how the teams make entry into a room: should they breach the door using a breaching charge? Should they throw in a flashbang or gas grenade before entering the room? You get the picture. You can also define the rules of engagement and movement speed of your teams for any waypoint. You can command them to be stealthy and only fire when fired upon for example or you can make them run and shoot on sight if you need to cover ground quickly to get to a hostage or bomb. The planner is awesome.

After you've finished planning your mission you can equip your teams any way you want. There's a lot of gear to choose from. There are light, medium and heavy armor and they affect your stealthiness and speed. Light armor is quiet and stealthy but does not offer much protection. Medium is a great balance and heavy armor looks kind of like riot gear and gives you extra protection but all your actions like switching weapons, turning around etc take a little longer to complete. You'll also be louder when you move. Then there are the weapons. There's a huge selection of SMG's, assault rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, pistols, machine pistols, grenades etc. There is also a selection of tactical gear like heartbeat sensors, demolition kits (to speed up defusing of bombs), lockpicking kits etc. You can equip each individual operative however you want.

When you get in the mission itself you can switch between teams and operatives to control them at any time or you can stick to controlling your guy and let the AI do it's job according to the plan you've set out for those teams. The friendly AI is very good. The trailing guy will cover the rear of your team and they are very aware of their surroundings and they are accurate as well when firing. They're also good at clearing rooms. They get through the door quickly and each operative will cover their own area of responsibility in the room. You can command your AI team mates on the fly to perform actions like clearing rooms using breaching charges, flashbangs, gas grenades etc. You can also command them to pick locks, defuse bombs or to escort hostages out of harms way. You can perform these actions yourself also. The damage modelling is pretty awesome. You suffer different effects depending on where you're shot (if you're lucky enough to only get wounded that is). Your aim suffers a lot if you get hit in your arm for example. You can't run and your walking slows if you get hit in the leg and so on. Good mission planning is crucial because you want your team members to survive the mission so you can use them again. You have a limited number of operatives of varying skill levels and specialties and if they get wounded they will need time to heal before you can use them again. If they die you lose them for the rest of the campaign. The sounds are awesome too.

The enemy AI could be a little better although there's nothing in their behaviour that would get really annoying during gameplay. Sometimes one of them will drop a grenade as he dies and after it goes off you can hear huh
date: what was that?" from the next room as if you can't tell when a frag grenade goes off in the hallway. They're pretty good at coming to investigate noises and stuff like that and they will use cover and get backup if you miss your shot and they get away. On the hardest setting they can be pretty brutal and it's tough to complete missions without any casualties to your team unless you've planned it perfectly.\n\nAfter you get the hang of the game you can get online and you'll find there are still people playing. You can play adversarial modes or you can play the campaign missions co-operatively with your friends
recommended: coordinating take downs etc. using teamspeak for example. Multiplayer requires a ubi.com account and the game does lack voice comms of it's own but those are not big minuses.\n\nThe game is still every bit as awesome as it was when it came out. The graphics are a bit dated but it will run like a dream in very high resolutions and with ridiculous amounts of AA and AF on. With those kinds of settings it looks pretty good. Also you can get a mod called Raven Shield 2.0 that will enhance the realism of the game to even higher levels adding things like iron sights and it also has higher resolution textures for the operators and terrorists enhancing the look of the game. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of tactical gaming and has somehow missed this gem. This is the best tactical shooter out there."

Being a game from 2003, the graphics look a bit rough, though that doesn't hurt the gameplay at all. You play as a sort of commander for the elite, international, blacker-than-black ops team Rainbow. Rainbow specializes in counter-terror and hostage rescue missions and are deployed when needed around the globe. This means that the levels take place across a variety of settings. You'll go from saving dignitaries in the Swiss alps to foiling bank robbers in London to clearing a mansion of baddies in the Cayman Islands. This keeps things unique and interesting throughout the game.
Each mission has a set pattern to it. You start by learning about the situation from Rainbow Six, the leader of Rainbow, and the other advisors with him. You then go to the team room where you select which operatives are going out on the mission, select their guns, armor, and other equipment, and choose what teams they'll be on. Then you go to the bread and butter of the game: the planning room. You are given a blueprint of the area and tasked with creating a plan for the teams to follow that will result in a successful mission. The planning system does take a bit of time to master but once the get the hang of things you'll find that the planning system is robust and customizable with a great depth to it. Once you have a plan created you can choose what team you'll be leading, in first person shooter style, through the action phase of the mission.
The action isn't as fast-paced as other games, but the methodical and tactical way that you can move through the area is unique, very enjoyable, and by no means boring. The action gameplay can shift from stealth to sychronized takedowns to all out gunfighting at a moments notice. The operatives and the terrorists all react realistically to bullets, meaning they die near-instantly. If that sounds too tough for the more tactical-minded gamers, you can also choose to observe the plan from a third-person flying camera and let the A.I take control of the operatives on the mission. You'll invariably find your plans don't always succeed, but there's much fun to be had from tweaking your plan until the teams move through the level like a well-oiled machine; to qoute the A-Team, I love it when a plan comes together." On a related note there are pre-made plans that you can load in if you find the planning system too much to handle or are frustrated with repeated failures.
The last great feature of the game is the custom mission option. This gives you access to all the maps that you've unlocked in the campaign and some that are only available in this mode and allows you to create a random mission from a good amount of mission types. Replaying story missions

reviewText:
Before the Review....

I just want to start out by saying that my hour count for this game is WAY different than what it should be. At launch, this game was well worn out by me and my crummy disc drive back in the day. I probably played 200+ hours total of this game, and half of those hours spent on Lan or on Ubisoft servers. This review will partially be based on those good and memorable times that I had, as well as the time that i spent owning this game over Steam. So if things sound unusual and out of perspective, it's probably because of me remembering the good ol' days of fast and tactical games. (Also not to mention the amount of bias put into here.) So, without further ado, here's the actual review...

The Rainbow Six games have always been a special gem in my heart. It's slow, creeping suspense and sudden firefights have always left a warm feeling in my heart. The old ones kept me in excitement, with every day of school meaning a night of fun with my friends and I. Rainbow Six 2 was always personally my favorite, giving the most diverse and exciting gameplay of its time. It was great.

However, those times ended, and my faith flew out the window when I was surpised to hear the next day that Ubisoft bought Red Storm out of the blue. This made the bright shining gem in my heart turn into a dark, twisted gem that I couldn't possibly light up again. How could Ubisoft create a great, diverse Rainbow Six game that follows the rules and dynamic systems that the previous installments had? I had little hope left, but something told me I had to try it. And so I bought the disc...

And it was AWESOME!

I shouldn't have let Ubisoft down. They left a hole in my heart, but somehow, they still managed to create a great game like all the rest. It was a polish of Rainbow Six 2, complete with weapon models, HD texture, and not-so-braindead AI. It was the most fun tactical shooters I had.

Rainbow Six 3 not only delivered the game to the fans, but delivered it with passion. It was such a great game that they couldn't have possibly dissapointed. The singleplayer was great, competative online was good, and LAN Parties over Co-op was the BEST. Even to today, I still invite my friend over with his PC, have some pizza, and play a little bit of this exhilirating shooter.

And then this Steam version came out, and, although the multiplayer services are down, (Thanks Ubisoft, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s) you can still get a good time out of this game.

So, as expected, here is a rundown of the scores...

Gameplay: 9.5/10
Graphics: 7/10 (Better than COD and BF though)
Multiplayer: 9/10
Enjoyment: 10/10

Recommendation: Everyone should give this game a try, but Rainbow Six # aims for tactical people who like to have a little fun with their friends. (And possibly not have friends anymore.... Just saying)

reviewText: When I think of the word tactical
date:
Rainbow Six 3 holds true to this word in every aspect.  Having played lots of modern first person shooters released nowadays, there's no newer modern fps I know of that is anything like this game.  I'd like to mention that I haven't touched the PvP in this game since it's pretty much dead from what I've seen, but I've experienced the campaign and co-op along with terrorist hunt, hostage rescue, etc. And I must mention that I was using the Ravenshield 2.0 mod through out my time with Rainbow Six 3. So here's what I feel the game does well at, and what it could've improved in certain areas.

+Very nice level of customization for weapons, gadgets, and soldiers.
+Very large amount of weapons to choose from.
+Lots of maps to play with; you can even use MP maps for solo plays.
+Customizable missions for terrorist hunt, hostage rescue, lone wolf, countdown.
+Less linear type of game, providing you with multiple ways on completing your objectives. From stealth, pure assault, or even both. Plus, using variety of weapons and gadgets to your preference.
+Good level design.
+Customizable squads up to 3 teams: Red, Green, and Gold.
+Preplanning is an amazing feature that lets you plan all your movement, and how you want you and your team to approach rooms inside any map, etc.  Any tactical game nowadays could use something like this.
+Challenging A.I.  They are pretty well designed enough for allowing you to play this game with tactical approach.
+Lots of tension, especially when playing at higher difficulties.
+A.I. spawn is somewhat randomized, so each playthrough should never exactly feel the same.
+With its good level design, preplanning, and customizable squads, it feels like there's a sandbox touch to the game. Because of this, you're provided with freedom and that gives very good amount of replayability, encouraging you to experiment.
+Rewards player with patience, skill, and careful movement. Seeing yourself beat missions can feel satisfying.
+Co-op is simply amazing and a real blast to play, especially when you and your partner(s) are going lone wolf; lots of communication and coordination together is encouraged to fully get the best experience possible with co-op.
+Playing it as a strategy game is possible with the help preplanning and spectator mode...so far with all these features, I don't think we could ask for a better SWAT-like game to be honest.

-Team A.I. can be dumb at times, this can be irritating.
-Hostages' location never change every time you start a new mission.
-While the enemy A.I. is challenging, they can also be dumb at times, too.
-Night vision is pretty terrible.
-You can't pick up ammo or weapons from dead enemies.
-Stealth mechanics aren't very well done, as a matter of fact, there's very little room for that.
-Difficulty progression in campaign isn't consistent, I've actually found some earlier levels harder than the later ones.
-Few reused maps in campaign (for me that's a no no), I always felt maps are a huge part of gameplay.

Rainbow Six 3 is a damn fine game and should be in any tactical game lover's collection. Even with some of its flaws, I can say without any doubt that this is easily one of the best tactical fps I've ever played. The sandbox touch to the game made so much difference to my impression with the game. The only other Rainbow Six games I've played are the Vegas games, and while they are fun, great games, they play nothing like its grand daddy. Now, I don't recommend this game to those who are into more arcade or fast paced fps, because R63 is nothing like that. Otherwise, for $9.99 excluding tax, it's easily worth that considering the amount of content and fun it provides. Go for it.
